From our latest podcast -- For three years (on Dec. 31, 1904-06), #NewYearsEve revelers gathered in Times Square to watch fireworks burst from the rooftop of the new New York Times building. The fireworks were replaced with a ball drop in 1907. https://bit.ly/2EMkloF pic.twitter.com/VRJDjsKUJA

From our latest podcast: Before Times Square, #NewYearsEve crowds gathered in front of Trinity Church, listening for the bells to usher in the coming year. This picture from 1906 depicts an old New York tradition on the wane. https://bit.ly/2EMkloF pic.twitter.com/yzii5tJHdt

Twitter -- 1913 style: "They resembled somewhat the tail of a comet, except that the comet was invisible." #bluelightpic.twitter.com/B3Mk4waVsV

IT'S HAPPENED BEFORE. In 1913, almost exactly 105 years ago (on Dec 28), strange lights above Brooklyn ("celestial phenomena") went unexplained. Possible explanations: Flashes of trolley wires on low clouds and violent flame discharges from a Gowanus Canal gas company. #bluelightpic.twitter.com/7JLJ0WQJvj

A New Year in Old New York: A history of celebration from Times Square to Chinatown. The last Bowery Boys podcast of 2018 -- released a day early! #HappyNewYear https://bit.ly/2EMkloF pic.twitter.com/y9b4WFtQpO

Flying back to New York City this week? If Fiorello La Guardia had gotten his way in the late 1920s, New York's official municipal airport would have been on Governors Island. Imagine your airplane landing here:  https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/hwGcFhghht

If you're tired of Christmas music, today you can listen to "Lullaby of Broadway," "Chattanooga Choo Choo" and "At Last." Harry Warren, composer of those songs and hundreds more, was born 125 yrs ago today, born Salvatore Antonio Guaragna to Italian immigrants in Brooklyn.pic.twitter.com/M4E0f9AoEJ

Fifty-five years ago today, Idlewild Airport was renamed John F. Kennedy Airport just weeks after the 35th president was assassinated in Dallas. And that newly-completed bridge linking Staten Island to Brooklyn was nearly named for JFK as well: https://bit.ly/2qg4IzO pic.twitter.com/N9jC0k0b0e

In 2018, we recorded shows on Grand Central, Penn Station, the Underground Railroad, New Amsterdam, Harry Houdini and the Brooklyn Dodgers. Presenting the top ten most popular Bowery Boys podcast episodes of 2018. We have released 30 episodes this year (with one to come next week), more material than ever before. Our top show of the year might surprise you! https://bit.ly/2A8fISE pic.twitter.com/fohDJL1buT

Why do many New Yorkers fly out of New Jersey? Why is LaGuardia Airport so important to the history of aviation? And how did Governors Island almost become a major airport? We answer those questions in our latest podcast -- perfect listening for travelers! https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/s1JMykFGJx

To those who support us on @Patreon -- check your emails! We've sent you a special podcast message for the holidays. Featuring news of future shows we're planning in 2019: https://bit.ly/2eriTYI pic.twitter.com/z3xUoGMjqw

The novella A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens was first published 175 years ago today in a sold-out print run of 6,000 copies. In 1955, WCBS-TV broadcast the first televised version of A Christmas Carol, transporting all the action to New York City: https://bit.ly/1SfDaA8 pic.twitter.com/bFaOyyv2HC

If you're on Instagram, there's a very cool video about the Lower East Side -- featuring us! @TravelLeisure invited us on a day-long tour as part of their new IGTV video series LOCALS featuring @tenementmuseum, @KatzsDeli,  @PianosNYC and more: http://bit.ly/2LnSpsu pic.twitter.com/84cxwiExlT

RIP Penny Marshall, the film director best known as the queen of TV comedy (w. Cindy Williams) on 8 seasons of Laverne & Shirley. She grew up living on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx. She later wrote, "I embraced being from the Bronx. To me, it was the center of the universe."pic.twitter.com/uFXHZItXAT
I'm sure there's some great older bios but the one I always suggest is Napoleon of New York by H. Paul Jeffers.

Robert Moses, the influential 'power broker' of New York City, builder of bridges, destroyer of neighborhoods, was born 130 years ago today in New Haven. Celebrate this holiday season with two original Christmas poems -- written by Robert Moses. https://bit.ly/2SXaobx pic.twitter.com/vPc1AGBKpr

It was New York City's lack of a proper airfield that kicks off an interesting chain of events in the 1920s, leading to the development of Newark Airport, Floyd Bennett Field and LaGuardia Airport. (4/4) https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/wZbgCctr7k

But it would be Hempstead Plains Aerodrome (east of NYC) that would become the region's most important airfield. In 1919 it was renamed @RooseveltField, named Theodore Roosevelt's son Quentin who died in air combat in World War I. (3/4) https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/lQHxnYNHXC

Wilbur Wright became the first man to fly an airplane over New York City on Sept. 29, 1909, taking off from a dirt runway on Governors Island. On one of those flights, he encircled the Statue of Liberty. (2/4) https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/twJKRZHYjv

Orville and Wilbur Wright became the first men to pilot a 'flying machine' 115 years ago today in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. That's where we begin in our latest episode, on the history of New York City's first airports (1/4) https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/kAjPyvKcJi
Wow thank you! Many of these are my favorites as well.

The new Bowery Boys podcast -- Newark vs. LaGuardia: The story of the first commercial airports and the first flying machines over New York City skies: https://bit.ly/2EmjuLe pic.twitter.com/dZmwO0cMou

RIP Nancy Wilson, one of the smoothest, most beautiful jazz voices in the world. She moved to New York in 1959 and almost instantly became a music recording star. In later years, she frequently performed at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village.pic.twitter.com/TRZopdXSTs
We were so excited to meet you too! Thanks for coming to the event.

On Friday's new Bowery Boys podcast, we're celebrating the 115th anniversary of the birth of flight by taking to the skies! Returning to the early days of commercial aviation and to a rivalry between the New York region's first major airports.pic.twitter.com/weUlyGIcdY

This Sunday, a rather unusual Christmas tradition returns to Washington Heights - a poetry reading and a candlelit procession through one of New York's oldest cemeteries: https://bit.ly/2C7LTTH pic.twitter.com/bwoT1rDp5A

Edward G. Robinson, Hollywood icon best known for playing gangsters in films like Key Largo and Little Caesar, was born 125 years ago today in Bucharest. At age 10, his family moved to America and lived on the Lower East Side. He later wrote, "At Ellis Island I was born again."pic.twitter.com/3OGq04eX6k

American Minerva, New York's first-ever daily newspaper, began publishing from a Wall Street printing house 225 years ago today. Its founder Noah Webster (better known for his dictionary @MerriamWebster) often used to newspaper to advertise his annual 'spelling books'.pic.twitter.com/ziQahbsUJ6

The original Santa con -- How a controversial cult leader who served jail time for child abduction became "the definitive Santa Claus of the 1910s and early 1920s" for New York commercial artists: https://bit.ly/2gm7edX   #SantaCon #santaconNYCpic.twitter.com/wmcahSWDyM

In its opening scenes, the film Green Book visits the Copacabana, a pillar of New York’s glamorous, volatile nightlife. A violent incident in the film early on nods to the Copa's most infamous, headline-grabbing incident - involving drunk New York Yankees. https://bit.ly/2StzTkK pic.twitter.com/jLXvFkTzbZ

Hear more from the Bowery Boys podcast -- on other people's podcasts and blogs! With @coreycambridge on his show @otherpeoplespodcast, Greg discusses the challenges of making a podcast. Madeline Kahn -- 'Clue' comedian, Mel Brooks' muse and star of several Broadway shows -- died of ovarian cancer on this date in 1999. In Central Park, you will find a bench dedicated to her memory, donated by her brother Jeffrey Kahn and husband John Hansbury.pic.twitter.com/ofRDxew19f

Maria Callas, one of the greatest opera stars of the 20th century, was born 95 years ago today in New York City, her parents newly arrived Greek immigrants. Her first years were spent in Astoria, then Washington Heights (where she began singing at the age of 10).pic.twitter.com/hgeACoSD3j

The new Bowery Boys podcast: The marvelous history of the New York City comedy scene. From vaudeville and the Village coffeehouses to @nbcsnl and the 1980s comedy-club boom. PLUS the origin of the most important brick wall in pop-culture history. https://bit.ly/2zvsvOv pic.twitter.com/zYNkerXcq3

In tomorrow's new Bowery Boys podcast, a century of laughter, the rascals and the revolutionaries -- from the vaudeville stage to the coffeehouses of Greenwich Village. And the story of the most important brick wall in entertainment history.pic.twitter.com/9PvVR8153H

Join us at the Yale Club for breakfast on Thursday, Dec 13! The Bard Birthday Breakfast benefits @NYPAProject, a not-for-profit organization dedicated to celebrating the history of historic preservation in New York City. https://bit.ly/2Q2sxI7 pic.twitter.com/0CL7JDWqaL

Madeleine L'Engle, author of A Wrinkle In Time, was born 100 yrs ago today in NYC. She's frequently associated w. @StJohnDivineNYC and was writer-in-residence there for years. She also volunteered at Cathedral library (now the Madeleine L’Engle Library). https://bit.ly/2rkMewn pic.twitter.com/muycgYxLQm

But you can still celebrate #EvacuationDay in lower Manhattan today (although we don't recommend you climb any flag poles). In 2017, Bowling Green was given a second name -- Evacuation Day Plaza. (5/5) https://bit.ly/2zqx38T  #EvacuationDaypic.twitter.com/VAc9hQlnR6

For decades, New Yorkers celebrated #EvacuationDay with parades and greased flagpole contests. But interest in these patriotic festivities had waned by 1864, the year Confederate saboteurs attempted to burn New York. (4/5) https://bit.ly/2zqx38T  #EvacuationDaypic.twitter.com/3zqFjb0Ud9

At that point, George Washington victoriously entered the city. He and his entourage of hundreds of soldiers had been waiting patiently at the Bull’s Head Tavern, awaiting the symbolic gesture at Fort George. (3/5) https://bit.ly/2zqx38T  #EvacuationDaypic.twitter.com/n7iSehZGic

British troops had nailed a Union Jack to the flagpole at Fort George, then greased the pole, making it impossible to remove. After several tries, a soldier named John Van Arsdale successfully scaled the pole and replaced the flag. (2/5) https://bit.ly/2zqx38T  #EvacuationDaypic.twitter.com/2ZKsYIb7vy

Today is #EvacuationDay, the original Brexit! The 235th anniversary of British troops leaving New York for good. At noon, the Union Jack would be lowered at Fort George and replaced with the American flag. But the British had one final trick to play! (1/5) https://bit.ly/2zqx38T pic.twitter.com/7WngVOOPSX
After reading these Tweets, you are most likely humming a certain song by now. #ScottJoplinhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fPmruHc4S9Q …

His grave went unmarked until 1974 thanks to a resurgence of his music used in the film 'The Sting'. Scott Joplin is today considered one of the greatest composers of the Gilded Age period. St. Michael’s Cemetery hosts annual  concerts in the spring. (4/4)pic.twitter.com/mXrVNvISD9

New York would destroy him. Unable to get his opera produced, he self-published music for a living. In 1916 he contracted syphilis and was admitted to Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island. He died of dementia in 1917, then buried in pauper’s grave with two other people. (3/4)pic.twitter.com/58MJUqp2KL

Joplin led the development of ragtime music in the 1890s, publishing classic tunes like ‘Maple Leaf Rag’ and ‘The Entertainer’ while living in Missouri, promoting the sound in saloons, clubs and even 1893 World's Fair. By 1907 he began composing opera and moved to New York. (2/4)pic.twitter.com/HlLQXWImGv

Scott Joplin, the king of ragtime music, was born 150 years ago this year. Although his true birth date is unknown, November 24 is often celebrated as the day he was born in Texas 1868. He died in 1917, and for 57 years, he was buried in an unmarked grave in Queens. (1/4)pic.twitter.com/Jmwyt5e7pe

Barons of the Sea: In @stevenujifusa adventurous new book, how tea, opium and the Gold Rush inspired New York merchants to build the fastest ships in the world.  https://bit.ly/2QhNU7I pic.twitter.com/Y7zTCJyARW
Off to watch the dog show and to start Thanksgiving brunch. Thanks for following along. Happy Thanksgiving! #MacysDayParade #HappyThanksgivingpic.twitter.com/hxv1zsfjIP

Bryant Gumbel interviewed Diana Ross in front of @NYHistory for the 1979 #MacysDayParade. She rode the @NYDailyNews float and holds a mocked-up Daily News newspaper with her image. (Getty Images) #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/lIc2xo5PcG

In 1979 Diana Ross appeared at the #MacysDayParade atop the New York Daily News' Big Apple float. For a delighted audience, she sang the song 'The Boss'. #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/6TpK61c3TK

Slight correction -- Fred Gwynne was high AND drunk. "Fred had brought along a bottle with him, wrapped in a paper bag, and he got fractured [drunk]. Fred was cussin’ at people. I just kept the music up so nobody could hear him." And there's video!https://bit.ly/2FzwqPW

Perhaps the most popular balloon in the history of #MacysDayParade is Underdog which first flew in 1965 and long outlasted the animated show, flying over New York 20 times. It was also the subject of an episode of 'Friends': https://bit.ly/2R7PXrV  #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/2b6yIRRJfx
It changed in 2009 to avoid Broadway and changed again in 2012 to avoid Times Square!

In 1964, the parade was first broadcast in color, and to jazz up the broadcasts, performers began lipsyncing for the first time, a now-treasured and awkward tradition. Betty White and Lorne Greene were the hosts. https://bit.ly/2FzwqPW   #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/oR2s5vVSCD
The defunct search-engine mascot Ask Jeeves appeared in the parade from 2000-2002 and 2004. https://bit.ly/2qZGvLS   #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/0SH0dU9MaV

Do you remember the Rex the Dinosaur balloon? It only flew in the parade once -- in 1993. During the parade, the dinosaur's head popped and floated the length of the parade looking horribly mutilated. https://bit.ly/2qZGvLS  #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/rOjL67BZXY

"Gwynne was high on ‘nerve medicine’ and began cursing at the crowd. Passing the hosts Lorne Greene and Betty White in the media box, Herman Munster fired off a rude expletive in their direction." https://bit.ly/2fv0H3t   #MacysParade #MacysDayParadepic.twitter.com/jiyOc7pIvI

In 1964 Al Lewis and Fred Gwynne, stars of the Munsters sitcom, made an appearance at the #MacysParade and they were totally high. https://bit.ly/2fv0H3t  #macysthanksgivingdayparade #MacysDayParadepic.twitter.com/XLYybYUSGS

Snoopy made his #MacysParade debut fifty years ago this season, but the iconic dog will not be seen in the skies of this year's parade. He's been replaced by his kite-wielding owner Charlie Brown. https://bit.ly/2Bq0n0K  #macysthanksgivingdayparade #MacysDayParadepic.twitter.com/B4crYOzLPx

In 1974, rising star Elton John performed at Madison Square Garden on Thanksgiving night and had a very special guest star -- John Lennon (in what would be his final stage performance). https://bit.ly/1T7lDIu  #MacysParade #HappyThanksgivingpic.twitter.com/ah7U8yWOEm

Most of the balloons and floats this year represent new pop-cultural characters and brands. Two of the oldest characters both happen to the green -- the Jolly Green Giant and the Sinclair Dinosaur (both late 1920s/early 1930s creations). #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/v5UZ2FzCpq

The #MacysDayParade was first broadcast nationally in 1948, but most Americans first saw it a year earlier on the big screen -- in Miracle on 34th Street. The film uses footage from the 1946 parade. https://bit.ly/2BlZms9  #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/89sU0v7DI5

The Radio City @Rockettes have performed in the #MacysDayParade since 1952 and have always been the official KICK-off for the parade.  https://bit.ly/2CcWon6  #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/nHHJzxEEAh

But New Englanders had celebrated a form of Thanksgiving for many years prior to 1863 proclamation, considered a regional feast (although often celebrated in New York too). Took off as a national event after the Civil War. http://bit.ly/2gjUVzl    #Thankful #ThanksgivingDay2018pic.twitter.com/c9sd0fFRKd

It was 155 years ago this year that Abraham Lincoln declared the first national celebration of Thanksgiving, to be held on the last week in November: https://bit.ly/2gjUVzl   #Thankful #ThanksgivingDay2018pic.twitter.com/XrlUJyyFyS
That's cool! Thank you for sharing.

For Thanksgiving masking, boys often wore girls clothing, “tog[ging] themselves out in worn-out finery of their sisters,” spending the afternoon “in awkward mimicry of their sisters to the casual street piano.” https://bit.ly/2TDtXan   #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/NxQK93AbAq

The original Macy's parade was inspired in part by 'ragamuffin parades' featuring kids in unusual costumes. Thanksgiving masking was a regional tradition “deeply rooted in the New York child.” https://bit.ly/2TDtXan  #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/HAxNPeuU9x

The first Thanksgiving parade was first held in 1924, featuring actual animals borrowed from the zoo. The first balloons introduced into the parade were released into the sky at parade's end. Imagine seeing this floating overhead: #MacysParade #macysthanksgivingdayparadepic.twitter.com/TaqME4DBZp

Tweeting along this morning with the #macysthanksgivingdayparade from somewhere nice and warm. For those watching the parade from outside, stay warm!  #MacysParade #HappyThanksgivingpic.twitter.com/lNET6OwvLP

Snoopy made his Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade debut fifty years ago, wearing World War I aviator goggles and helmet. William Shatner was there also, dressed as James T. Kirk. And, being 1968, there were also protesters: https://bit.ly/2Bq0n0K  #MacysParade #ThanksgivingEvepic.twitter.com/wWC2LCHY7h

Kent did not attend the unveiling of her LOVE postage stamp out of protest in 1985. She had wanted it held at the United Nations; instead it was unveiled on the Love Boat set in Burbank, CA -- ironically the same year that Andy Warhol made an appearance on "The Love Boat." (2/2)pic.twitter.com/V5BHYK0Eoi

The Roman Catholic nun Corita Kent was born 100 years ago today in Fort Dodge, Iowa. She was also silkscreen artist, heavily influenced by Andy Warhol, and her art was particularly popular with the anti-war movement. In 1985 she designed the LOVE postage stamp. (1/2)pic.twitter.com/spVQnTHuSB

America’s first memorial to World War I sits in Battery Park, the gift of Fifth Avenue’s ‘tinplate king’, transforming one of New York’s oldest piers into an elegant timepiece. https://bit.ly/2z8xeWe pic.twitter.com/rI67o79g4A
The Tiger by Oliver Allen and Kenneth Ackerman’s Boss Tweed biography.

James Renwick Jr., one of the most acclaimed American architects of the 19th century, was born 200 years ago today in New York City. Among his most famous New York buildings -- @StPatsNYC, the Roosevelt Island Smallpox Hospital and @GraceChurchNYC: https://bit.ly/2JUBe0J pic.twitter.com/b0zJTDae6a

For other landmarks of World War I in New York City, we highly recommend 'World War I New York: A Guide to the City’s Enduring Ties to the Great War' by @k72ndst. https://bit.ly/2qWlzqa   #ArmisticeDay100 #ThankYouForYourServicepic.twitter.com/3cQRdgcICk

Battery Park also contains an important artifact to World War I -- the Pier A clocktower, unveiled on January 25, 1919 and considered the first WWI memorial in the United States. https://bit.ly/2T0vB5z   #ArmisticeDay100 #ThankYouForYourServicepic.twitter.com/I1nrlgDdyf

In Battery Park, the doll representing Kaiser Wilhelm II was burned in effigy. From NY Times: "soldiers and sailors executed a war dance around the flames 'to the tune of a hand organ'." https://bit.ly/2T3ajUP  https://nyti.ms/2z41emh   #ArmisticeDay100 #ThankYouForYourServicepic.twitter.com/ocSkbAnbcM

Thousands of New Yorkers gathered on Wall Street at the Sub-Treasury Building (today's @FederalHallNPS) and at City Hall to celebrate the armistice. Air raid sirens blared, this time eliciting joyful cheers. https://bit.ly/2T3ajUP   #ArmisticeDay100 #ThankYouForYourServicepic.twitter.com/b7wgpOAOL6

The most powerful image from a New York newspaper came the day before Armistice when the New York Tribune provided "5,000 Reasons For Unconditional Surrender."  https://bit.ly/2T3ajUP   #ArmisticeDay100 #ThankYouForYourServicepic.twitter.com/3RJl2dIe8u

The @BklynEagle celebrated the end of the war with daily illustrations on their front page. Once used for thoughtful reflection, the cartoon box finally got to have a little fun with its subject matter.  #ArmisticeDay100pic.twitter.com/VL7sq1nKAn

One hundred years ago today, Americans woke to the news that an armistice, signed by the Allied powers and Germany, ended the battles of the Great War. Many months later, the Treaty of Versailles would end it altogether. #ArmisticeDay100pic.twitter.com/eidMCXR59d

BONUS TWEET: Gotham-Attucks also produced what has to be the best song title in the history of American Music -- "You're In The Right Church But The Wrong Pew." (Images in these tweets courtesy @nypl and @librarycongress)pic.twitter.com/2cEczGIPLk

The company lasted only a few years, but its team of songwriters would go on to change the landscape of American popular music. Gotham-Attucks is but one of many reasons to celebrate Tin Pan Alley today and why that which remains should be preserved. (9/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/ziFbf9nA93

Gotham-Attucks published songs by black writers that disavowed those ugly stereotypes. And its sheet-music artwork, by a team of unknown illustrators, presented African-American faces in normal naturalistic way by comparison. (8/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/gonwl2Psid

The American popular songwriting tradition grew out of the minstrel circuit, and even by the 20th century, white musicians sang 'coon songs' featuring grotesque, racist images of black people on its sheet music. (7/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/Dfbw3lSNuP
But Gotham-Attucks was revolutionary in another aspect -- its sheet-music artwork. (6/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/J1SJ5lzahm

Gotham Attucks' roster of songwriters included some legendary African-American music artists (Will Marion Cook, James Tim Brymn). But the most famous was Bert Williams who later found fame with Ziegfeld. GA published his signature song 'Nobody' (5/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/IZWnuxAg1p

The merged Gotham-Attucks Music began music publishing in 1905 at 47 West 28th St, a lane bustling with dozens of song sellers -- all white owned. Gotham-Attucks took a unique approach, marketing song (by mostly black writers) to a general audience. (4/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/gVC63MWt02

Attucks Music, formed by Shepard N. Edmonds in 1904, gives a nod to Revolutionary War history in its name. Crispus Attucks, a Boston man of African and Native American descent, was the first person killed in the Boston Massacre in 1770. (3/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/5HixSYWEle

The composer Cecil Mack (born RC McPherson), who began Gotham Music in 1904, would write for several publishers in his lifetime and was compared to Stephen Foster. In 1906 he wrote music w. James Reese Europe for the musical The Black Politician. (2/9) http://bit.ly/2PGdQcC pic.twitter.com/cuQ2h7v1ON

In our latest podcast on Tin Pan Alley, NYC's former music district on West 28th St, we highlighted Gotham-Attucks Music, believed to be the first black operated music company in America. Following the play's closure, Reynolds left New York and moved to Hollywood. From his memoir, "I fell in love with New York. Unfortunately it did not fall in love with me." Rip Torn would go on to be a huge Broadway star, starring (in 1959) in the premiere of Sweet Bird of Youth -- opposite Paul Newman. Buddy Reynolds would make his Broadway debut in 1961 in a play called LOOK! We've Come Through. The play closed after 3 days.pic.twitter.com/agyTwg7bPr

Reynolds became friends with actor Rip Torn (pictured, in 1960) at the Actors Studio, and the two roomed together for a time in Hell's Kitchen. 'Buddy' Reynolds would drop out of the Actors Studio and work with Stanford Meisner.pic.twitter.com/z7WRblBRmJ

Reynolds makes note in his biography to say "I ate most of my meals at the Horn & Hardart automat on 42nd Street. It was a great place to eat if you were on a budget." The automat allowed struggling actors a decent cheap meal. The 42nd Street automat was last to close (in 1991).pic.twitter.com/VKtOuq0iCU

As a struggling actor in New York, Reynolds (billed as Buddy Reynolds) took odd jobs through the city, working at the docks and waiting tables. Notably, he was a bouncer at the Roseland Ballroom for a time. https://bit.ly/2NVlzzI pic.twitter.com/u1fAnl8qlT

At 19 years old, he came to New York following a stint in Hyde Park, doing 'Tea and Sympathy' with rising star Joanne Woodward. According to his bio, he initially propositioned Woodward in NY, only to be told, "I'd like you to meet my boyfriend Paul Newman."pic.twitter.com/jRZMUtfoco

For a heartbreaking imagining of the tragedy of St. Claire Pollack, check out this remarkable comic by @rfressonOK published in the New York Times in 2017. (10/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/HNAbpSVL8U

Today a small road leading out of Riverside Park is named St. Clair Place. This makes the Amiable Child the youngest person to ever have a New York street named after them. (9/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/8aOyVrht4T

St. Claire Pollack has inspired dozens, maybe even hundreds, of poems, although the best known is by Anna Catherine Markham "At Riverside on the slow hill-slant/Two memoried graves are seen": (8/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/fTatHKxY79

In 1900, a paper ‘found’ Pollack in the Trinity Church baptism logs. “The grave is known to as many persons as that of Grant himself. A pilgrimage to Grant’s Tomb is regarded as incomplete without a look at the Amiable Child’s resting place." (7/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/EGxvqcz8nW

The grave of the Amiable Child is perpetually adorned with flowers and plants. In 1899 an asphalt walk was built around the grave to accommodate visitors to the spot. (6/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/thqacRqUaW

But the child’s grave was considered a ‘Romantic spot’ well before the death of Grant. In 1879, the NY Herald points out the grave “hidden among primeval trees” next to a bust of George III – which is no longer there. (5/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/Lfk3yazLDh

Claremont Inn, a popular restaurant located near Grant’s Tomb, attracted many sightseers to this high point in the park. Enjoying the commanding, windswept heights, visitors stumbled upon the Amiable Child Monument and became instantly intrigued. (4/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/3GIRbaILND

The juxtaposition of two gravesites – about 400 feet from each other – one to a former president and the other to a small boy, has made this section of Riverside Park into a spot of great contemplation. But it has also inspired countless poets. (3/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/RKtm9d9Q32

One hundred years later, in 1897, the imposing tomb of Ulysses S. Grant and his wife Julia was completed, rising around the carriage loop of Riverside Drive. Grant’s Tomb would instantly become one of America’s top tourist attractions. (2/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/DpWC4D6ySW

In 1797 a five-year-old boy named St. Claire Pollack was killed when he fell from a cliff overlooking the Hudson River. His bereaved parents buried him on a plot near their home. Today this grave --  to “an Amiable Child” -- sits in Riverside Park. (1/11) https://bit.ly/2o6gXLu pic.twitter.com/uz4YFJeLdf

Please visit an animal shelter this weekend and consider adopting an animal in need! In particular, @GregoireNYC recommends @AnimalHaven in Little Italy (just few blocks south of the old Lafayette hospital) where he got his dog Maisie. #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/FsERn1YZFD

While the hospital is long gone, this landmark to pet lovers still stands today at the corner of Lafayette and Bond, a couple blocks north of the Puck Building.   http://bit.ly/2MxZQAb   #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/W8RFOg4sZX

Animal care and responsible pet ownership was an important component of the progressive cause. “You don’t find wife-beaters who are fond of pets and lovers of animals,” League reformers wrote in an editorial in 1912. https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb  #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/f1EJFZn78j

In fact, in 1907, a few years before the hospital's opening, New Yorkers experienced a 'monkey craze', with hundreds of poor animals as pets in households ill-equipped to provide for them. https://bit.ly/2L3CLke  #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/3XntlzPkuo

But New York faced another animal crisis -- unwanted pets. The city was filled with thousands of animals (many exotic and dangerous) and few options for care. The Central Park Zoo grew out of a menagerie of unwanted animals in 1860s.  https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb   #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/dDRqw7XfpW

Speyer and the women's ASPCA organized a Work Horse Parade in 1907, giving prizes for healthy animals. Horse obstacle-course competitions were held in Union Square. https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb  #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/KOy6xfekBO

The hospital was the brainchild of Ellin Prince Speyer, wife of prominent banker James Speyer. She started a women's branch of @ASPCA in 1906, quickly organizing public displays that would bring attention to the plight of work animals. https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb  #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/uMACwPrVgS

The Free Hospital cared for hundreds of horses on the second floor. A rooftop garden accommodated the most sickly horses in need of fresh air and sunshine, lifted there by a large, state-of-the-art elevator.  https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb   #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/TwXA3Jw5zG

It was located at 350 Lafayette Street. The facility could accommodate fifty horses and 150 cats and dogs. “There are also operating rooms where every modern appliance for animal surgery is at hand.” https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb   #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/eNAqaI739t

Did you know that the first free animal hospital in America -- one that specialized in pets, not just horses and farm animals -- opened on Lafayette Street (north of Houston) in 1914? https://bit.ly/2MxZQAb  #ClearTheShelterspic.twitter.com/MC3zvJCogj

The Stone/Blackwell marriage arrangement shattered norms of the era, protesting a husband's "custody of the wife's person," "sole ownership of her personal and use of her real estate," and "exclusive control and guardianship of their children." The model of a modern marriage.pic.twitter.com/BXBBevHaFd

"A wife should no more take her husband's name than he should hers. My name is my identity and must not be lost." Stone married Henry Browne Blackwell in 1855; they struck up an unprecedented agreement (essentially a 19th century pre-nup), promising true equality in marriage.pic.twitter.com/hs2knUrqkR

Lucy Stone, early advocate for women's equality and the abolition of slavery, a fearless woman who wore bloomers, kept her last name, spoke out against unequal pay and inspired a new generation of female leaders, was born 200 years ago today in West Brookfield, MA.pic.twitter.com/goWjrPZuHp

While the shop left Sixth Avenue many years ago, @martinkamagic is still around as a New Jersey-based on-line retailer. From their website, a picture of the Martinka brothers, the founders of this magic empire: https://bit.ly/2nxaoRT pic.twitter.com/D3BviGu2Va

In 1920, Martinka & Co was actually owned by Harry Houdini, although he quickly passed it on to other great magician owners, including Carter the Great (who kept his pet lion Monty here). http://bit.ly/2Mey7V7 pic.twitter.com/w9TCgKsC6G

While Martinka's celebrated the craft of stage magic, it did dabble in the more popular aspects of spiritualism. Even as society members like Harry Houdini worked to debunk certain forms of spiritualism, Martinka's stocked its shelves with Ouija boards: http://bit.ly/2Mey7V7 pic.twitter.com/3ftwnSKQFp

But it was Martinka's back room that was world renown, a secret space for professional magicians to design and try out new tricks and routines. In 1902 the Society of American Magicians was founded here, marking its status as a magic mecca. http://bit.ly/2Mey7V7  @sammumnewspic.twitter.com/HT0sDUShRR

Martinka & Co, which opened in 1877, became one of America's leading magic shops, selling mechanical monkeys and automatons that played chess, its shelves loaded w. items like “The Wonderful Cigarette Paper Trick,” and “The Mystic Barrel of Salt.” https://bit.ly/2Mey7V7 pic.twitter.com/xzcWVY99bn

From our newest podcast -- A very mysterious shop once sat on Sixth Avenue in the shadow of the elevated train, owned by German immigrants Francis and Antonio Martinka. It would come to be known as the Palace of Magic: https://bit.ly/2Mey7V7 pic.twitter.com/ua45updMPQ

And @GregoireNYC spoke about Bertha's famous journey in last years episode of @TheFirstPodcast on America's first long-distance road -- the Lincoln Highway. https://bit.ly/2Bw99fy pic.twitter.com/mjAQvweQKa
Today, drivers can take Benz' path to notoriety along the Bertha Benz Memorial Route. It should take you less than an hour to drive.pic.twitter.com/MHYTYH7n8x

Bertha's long-distance drive (on August 5, 1888) was not without peril. She employed her garter and hat pins for makeshift repairs and made frequent stops to local chemists (the only place to buy petrol). Leaving in the morning, the trio arrived in Mannheim just before dark.pic.twitter.com/eSAkoj4IKw

While the 'reason' for their trip was to visit Bertha's mother, she was determined to get some publicity for her husband's invention. Benz had received the patent for the automobile in 1886 but was finding it difficult to shore up investors.pic.twitter.com/FXexgfKCBv

Today is the 130th anniversary of the first automobile road trip and it is AMAZING. Bertha Benz, wife of inventor Karl Benz (as in @MercedesBenz), drives her two sons Richard and Eugen 106 km (or 66 miles) from Mannheim to Pforzheim, Germany, without her husband's permission.pic.twitter.com/l52ToIiFAH

(As @MaPoStormborn points out, President Buchanan's telegraph message back to Queen Victoria would make it the very first of many presidential electronic communications in history. Except his was delivered via Morse code, not Tweets.)pic.twitter.com/uk87bIhpJ7

For the rest of the story, listen to our latest podcast on the Atlantic Cable! Featuring the origin of Field's ambitious project and the arduous and frustrating journey to getting his vision realized -- through the wilderness, under the sea, into history. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/DhATOBwK2r

Cyrus West Field arrived in New York by Sept. 1, 1858, the man of the hour who persevered to bring North America and Europe -- and more precisely, their financial markets -- closer together. But New York's celebration was about to be brought to a halt. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/uqFHjkmIu9

New Yorkers were so jubilant in their celebration of the Atlantic Cable that City Hall was nearly destroyed in a blaze of fireworks. The cupola was incinerated and the city's legal documents were nearly lost. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/D8oTi6gptJ

The news of the first transatlantic telegraph message was met as though it came from God. The New York Times declared "The Old World and The New United. Gloria In Excelsis."  https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/AJBh8982fO

Many days later (August 16), a message from London was finally received, and it was doozy -- a 99-word greeting from Queen Victoria. President James Buchanan responded with an equally verbose reply: https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/8HQLmILWSf

The world celebrated this transatlantic link as 'the great event of the modern age', despite the fact that no message had yet been received. For a moment, the world seemed that much smaller. A hymn to the Atlantic Cable ran in a New York newspaper: https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/rDLCdVoCaM

Laying the Atlantic Cable was an arduous, often dangerous task and took years to complete, waylaid by storms, broken links, poor planning and even sabotage. It eventually took two warships -- HMS Agamemnon and USS Niagara -- to carry the line. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/gUTbzlDSZi

The Atlantic Cable project was led by a young retired New York businessman named Cyrus West Field and a group of investors and thinkers assembled as the Cable Cabinet. This group included Samuel Morse and Peter Cooper, Field's Gramercy Park neighbor. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/NAnx9R2fIM

The world forever changed 160 years ago today. An undersea connection known as the Atlantic Cable, linking Europe and North America, made land in Newfoundland and in western Ireland. London could communicate with New York via telegraph. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/QDmScKtNPs

The Atlantic Cable celebration on Sept 1, 1858, culminated in a procession from City Hall to New York Crystal Palace, the former home of America's first world's fair. Just a month later, on Oct 5, 1858, the Crystal Palace would also burn down. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/TXvJ2itWxD

Now you might ask -- why would NYC allow dangerous fireworks to be discharged in a city comprised of wooden buildings? In fact fireworks were manufactured and sold here for many decades ONE BLOCK AWAY from City Hall, on a street nicknamed Firecracker Lane: https://bit.ly/29licjY pic.twitter.com/G7RqsU8lPV

But the party wasn't over! When Cyrus Field, the mastermind of the Atlantic Cable project, finally arrived in town on September 1, 1858, celebrations in New York renewed again. City Hall was central to those festivities too -- sans its destroyed cupola. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/9y6LnCCMWT
....but unfortunately they caught the cupola on fire. New York City Hall -- and all the city's documents -- were almost destroyed in the blaze. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/W8usyD6EGK

New York truly went wild when the first telegraph message was delivered on August 16  -- a lengthy statement by Queen Victoria. The following day the entire city erupted in all-day celebration. Fireworks blazed from the top of New York City Hall.... https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/A6PETQhnl5

New Yorkers began celebrating on August 6, 1858, at news that the transatlantic cable had successfully touched down between Newfoundland and Ireland. No message had been sent but New York nearly shut down in celebration of the link. https://bit.ly/2AiXRLh pic.twitter.com/DUIXZTo4zn

Instead, as the city planners decided more open public space was necessary, the meeting or 'union' of Broadway and the Bowery was extended up to 14th Street and turned into a park -- Union Square (or Union Place, as it was first called) https://bit.ly/2LecSPy pic.twitter.com/FQBJLuL5bD
In the original Commissioners Plan of 1811, Broadway and the Bowery were to 'disappear' into a gigantic parade ground at around 23rd Street. https://bit.ly/2LecSPy pic.twitter.com/psBWQIZaCt
In an abandoned street plan from the 1810s, Broadway and the Bowery eventually merge and become one road. https://bit.ly/2LecSPy pic.twitter.com/eo0Rr4fdVq

From our latest podcast on the origins of Broadway: The street begins its diagonal cut up Manhattan at 10th Street. Why?
